subject: Use proper status code for partial content

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I prefer to fix this issue until https://review.openstack.org/#/c/136039/ get merged (will in the next 0.11.1 release, as current planed), due to current store driver doesn't really care about range require.
Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Any HTTP response which returns only a range/part of the requested object should always return 206 Partial Content.

How would one exercise this via a HTTP rest request using curl:

GET /v2/images/image-uuid as per API definition only returns information about the image.

GET /v2/images/image-uuid/file will download the actual image itself.

I would have expected:
url -i -X GET -r 0-20 -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" $image_url/v2/images/{image_id}/file

to fetch partial content however it does not, Range requests don't work at all from what I can see.
Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated

Patch Set 3:

Adding "Depends-On" will ensure this doesn't merge before I76fd3746a2c449e257ea2a19c2dc6118be207eec

Patch Set 3:

A couple of high level comments (some of which are probably out of scope).

1) We need to show that we are being consistent w.r.t potentially backward incompatible changes

eg, this change was -1'd for breaking compatability:

 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/159068/

Anything which currenly checks for '200' will be affected by the current change.

(FWIW when swift had a similar issue they stuck with the 'wrong' value:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/19617/)

What is different about this change that makes it ok to merge? Thanks.

2) Do we need to do a better job of managing anything that changes the API?

eg https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154704/ changed the API without reaching consensus.

Would requiring a spec for anything that changes the API (even bugfixes) be overkill?

3) Similarly, should an API version bump also be required?

4) Any idea where Glance's v2 support for content-range is documented (ie outside the code base)?

5) From the code it looks like we're also not returning a header such as 'Content-Range: bytes 10223616-10485759/10485760' in our responses. Should we?

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)
Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Hi Stuart,

I think backward-compatibility is key point for api, but for this change I see it just want to make wrong thing to be correct, when a Range header is provided (Content-Range should be correct to Range), glance should response partial content to client just follow http rfc and 206 code given. Then following http rfc is my second point (for your last point), as I mentioned in the inline comment, I'm sure currently glance needs to be enhanced to cover http rfc spec fully and correctly for partial download.

Thoughts? Thanks.
Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1
Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1
Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Unfortunately, this change does break backwards compatibility and we can't allow that. :/

I don't see how we could make this change backwards compatible, which means we may need an API version bump.

Somehow, I wonder if it's worth it to bump the version just for this. Are there other changes to the content-range implementations that we need?

Patch Set 3:

Stuart: I have to double check about returning that header but I think you're correct.

Flavio: Yes it's a breaking change, but currently everything about Range requests are broken right now. With Zhi Yan Liu's capabilities change from last cycle, we should be able to fix them all at once. This is a piece of that puzzle.

Patch Set 3:

Agree with Ian. There is no way to get partial content today. Even adding 'Content-Range' header will not work (even though it's not the right header).
So I don't see how someone could be affected by this currently unusable feature of the API.

Abandoned

We'll revist this if we decide to do another version bump for the Glance API. Until then, users will have to be continuously baffled by the wrong response to a range request.
